Louisville freshman excited to return from suspension

Himmelsbach | Shaqquan Aaron says he's ready

Adam Himmelsbach, ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com 3:26 p.m. EST December 10, 2014

Video | Relieved Shaqquan Aaron ready to play first Louisville game

June 13-15, 2013: Shaqquan Aaron during the NBA Players Association Top 100 camp at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, VA.(Photo: Kelly Kline)

19 CONNECT 26 TWEETLINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE

NEW YORK—Shaqquan Aaron sat quietly at his locker after Louisville's 94-74 win over Indiana on Tuesday night, just like he has done after most games this season.

But this time, there was an unusual sight. This time, there was a smile.

"I'm really excited," Aaron said. "I just can't wait to get out on that court."

The freshman wing from greater Seattle had missed the season's first seven games as the NCAA investigated his amateur status. On Tuesday, just a few hours before U of L faced the Hoosiers, the NCAA handed down a nine-game suspension after determining that Aaron had received "extra benefits related to housing" while in high school. U of L was not involved in that matter.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Louisville basketball freshman Shaqquan Aaron cleared by the NCAA

In addition to the suspension, Aaron's family will also have to repay the housing money and Aaron will be required to perform community service. While it was surely not the finding that the Aaron family had hoped for, the bottom line is he will have to sit out just one more game—Sunday against North Carolina-Wilmington-- before being eligible to play.

And after a long, trying process, the realization that his college career can finally begin left Aaron determined, optimistic and ready to make up for lost time.

"It's been tough," he said. "I mean, there's two different ways to look at it: Either you can be sad and not work, or just look at it as just putting a fire in you to work, and I've just been working and waiting for my opportunity."

Yes, the NCAA is a flawed organization. But a narrative emerged that it was dragging its feet when in reality we don't know if it was simply conducting a thorough investigation. The NCAA owed it to Aaron not to put his case on the back burner, but it was not required to act hastily just because basketball season had started. Ultimately, if Aaron had received this suspension last summer, he would be in the exact same position as he is now.

MORE: Rozier, Harrell lead Louisville over Indiana

MORE: Himmelsbach | Give us more Cards-Hoosiers

On Tuesday, Aaron maintained that he and his family did nothing wrong, but he said he did not want to speak further about the case, preferring to focus on the fact that it is over. He's glad to be cleared and the Cardinals are glad to have him. And the rest of the college basketball world is probably uneasy about this powerful Louisville team adding another weapon.

Aaron continued to practice with the Cardinals throughout the NCAA investigation, and that should allow a fairly seamless transition into the rotation. Aaron said that in addition to participating in regular practices, he has spent countless hours in the gym working on his jump-shot, working to get ready for his debut, even though he never knew when that day might come.

"It's been difficult, but I would say it's kind of a learning aspect too, because sitting on the bench I'm seeing things that you can't see when you're playing," he said. "So when I'm ready to play, I'd know the little things that I saw or something my teammates should do…I look at it both ways. Of course it was tough watching, but it's a positive, too."

Aaron should give U of L some added scoring punch when he returns for the Dec. 20 game against Western Kentucky. He is widely viewed as the most talented player in this freshman class.

"Shaqquan is going to give us a good lift," Cardinals coach Rick Pitino said Tuesday night.

Aaron said he never considered the possibility that he might miss the entire season. He has just been working and waiting, and now he is eager to get started.

"I haven't played a basketball game in a while, so it'll be exciting," he said. "I'll probably be a little nervous, but as soon as the ball goes up in the game, all the nerves go out the window, so I'll be good."

Adam Himmelsbach can be reached at 502-582-4372 by email ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com and on Twitter @adamhimmelsbach
